prop.head.headtext: Legal Bases Used by the Courts for the Protection of Confidential Business Information

head.headtext: Criticism—Basis for the Equitable Obligation of Good Faith Is the Right to the Property

para.paratext: While it is clear that the courts of the Commonwealth and the United States have adopted the concept of an equitable duty to safeguard confidential information where a party receives the information in confidence, the duty arises only because the owner has a right to the information itself. Even the words used to describe the equity are words often used to describe property. In the words of Professor Scott, a party who appropriates confidential business information is deemed to be a “trespasser”, thus allowing the rightful owner of the property to exert an “equitable lien” over the property.[1]
A.W. Scott, Law of Trusts, 3rd ed. (Boston, Mass.: Little, Brown, 1967), vol. 5, s. 509, p. 2593.
